Kawng Il Koh, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Orthopedic Surgery   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2758
smears did not show any evidence of TB. Based on the biopsy results, 
we consulted with an internal medicine of tuberculosis specialist 
and started the patient on a daily anti-TB regimen, HRZE, which 
included isoniazid 100 mg (H), rifampin 600 mg (R), pyrazinamide 
500 mg (Z), and ethambutol 400 mg (E). During follow-up, she 
complained a limited range of motion (ROM) and continuous knee 
pain in her everyday life. Follow-up x-rays showed rapid 
degenerative changes to the knee along with destruction of the joint. 
After 9 months of treatment with HRZE, the patient’s day-to-day life 
had become difficult due to the pain caused by the severe destruction 
of 
the knee joint (Figure 4A and B). A total knee arthroplasty (TKA) 
and biopsy were performed (Figure 5). Additional TB treatment 
regimen(HR) was continued for a year to prevent a recurrence of 
infection due to TB reactivation a
fter TKA [4]. The patient recovered 
without 
any infection at the operation site, and experienced a 
postoperative alleviation of her pain with no sign of recurrence of the 
cystic mass (Figure 
6). The patient maintained without a recurrence 
of a tuberculous infection 5 years after the TKA.
Discussion
The knee is the third most common site of extrapulmonary 
TB, accounting for about 10% of skeletal TB lesions [8]. The most 
common symptom of skeletal TB is diffuse swelling with a subsequent 
progressive loss of movement. Occasionally it can manifest as multiple 
discharging sinuses and a triple deformity of the knee [8]. Although 
rare, the occurrence of a Baker's cyst along with TB of the knee has 
been previously described [1,5].
A Baker's cyst is defined as a collection of fluid in the 
gastrocnemius–semimembranosus bursa of the knee, and usually 
results from an anatomical defect at the bursa–joint interface, 
compounded by pathologies which cause effusion of the knee 
[3,7]. The causes of knee effusions are commonly noninfectious, 
and secondary to meniscal tears, chondral lesions, osteoarthritis, 
Figure 1: (A) Preoperative findings showed a 7 x 15cm , soft mass on the 
medial side of the left calf. (B) The radiographic examination performed at 
the patient’s first visit showed normal alignment and non-specific findings.
Figure 2:  Cystic formation with a low signal on T1-weighted magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI), and a high signal on T2-weighted MRI findings 
before surgery. (A) An elongated complex cystic mass between the 
semimembranosus and medial gastrocnemius muscles. Distal inferomedial 
extension of the cyst suggested dissection of a popliteal cyst. (B) Diffuse, 
thick synovial proliferation involving the joint capsule.
Figure 3:  (A) Intraoperative findings showing adhesion with surrounding 
tissue and unclear margins. (B) After excision, the knee had granulation 
tissues with an irregular surface, and showed a different pattern from a 
Baker’s cyst. (C) Microscopic examination(H&E staining, x200) showed 
caseous granuloma with scattered multinucleated giant cells (black arrows). 
These findings were consistent with tuberculosis.
Figure 4:  (A) At 3 months after surgery, radiography showed osteopenic 
state and mild swelling. (B) At 9 months after surgery, imaging showed 
severe joint destruction, even after treatment with anti-tuberculosis drugs. 
Figure 5: The biopsy was performed during the TKA. There demonstrated 
the epithelioid cells with Langhans giant cells (arrows) and caseous necrosis 
(arrowheads). (H&E, x200). 
Figure 6: Radiograph showed without a recurrence of the tuberculous 
infection at 5 years after the TKA.

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Kawng Il Koh
metadata.title: Rapidly Progressive Tuberculous Arthritis of the Knee Following Excision of a Tubercular Cystic Mass Misdiagnosed as a Baker’s Cyst: A Case Report

page_content:
3
Kawng Il Koh, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Orthopedic Surgery   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2758
seronegative/seropositive spondyloarthropathy, or pyrophosphate 
arthropathy [4,5]. Although uncommon, infective etiologies can also 
result in a Baker's cyst. Labropoulos et al. [7] confirmed in a casual 
analysis study the rare occurrence of a tubercular etiology in a 
Baker’s cyst. The presence of a tubercular popliteal cyst has been 
previously reported in a patient with tubercular arthritis, and can 
present as a ruptured popliteal cyst secondary to tubercular arthritis.
A 
Baker's cyst by itself has no specific radiographic features, but 
features of causative pathology can, at times, be seen on radiographs. 
In our case, we did not find anything significant on the radiographs 
of the knee. Osteoarticular TB has classical radiographic features, 
such as the Phemister triad, which consists of juxta-articular 
osteoporosis, peripheral osseous erosions, and narrowing of the 
joint space; however, in the early stages, radiographic features are 
usually nonspecific [8]. The slow growth pattern of Mycobacterium 
tuberculosis and a deficiency of proteolytic enzymes explain the 
preservation of the joint space in the early stage of osteoarticular TB 
[9]. These early changes are better detected on MRI, which shows 
articular affection and synovial thickening, as seen in the case of our 
patient [6].
Our patient complained of pain and a di ffuse swelling over 
the proximal aspect of her left calf. The MRI of the left leg revealed a 
popliteal cyst (probably an infectious etiology) with no other 
abnormalities; hence, we planned excision and biopsy. Our patient 
started an anti-TB regimen as soon as the histopathology report 
confirmed a diagnosis of tubercular synovitis. Despite a complete 
excision of the cyst and appropriate anti-TB medication, the patient 
suffered residual functional impairment due to pain and joint 
destruction, as demonstrated at 9 months follow-up. It is thought 
that immune insufficiency due to the long-term use of steroids to 
treat a vitiligo a
ffects the activation of TB and joint destruction [2]. 
Following this thought process, we decided to perform a TKA to treat 
her rapidly progressed extrapulmonary TB-induced arthritis with 
anti-TB drugs.
Conclusion
This case highlights that an infected Baker’s cyst can be a rare 
cause of unilateral lower-extremity pain and swelling. An infected or 
ruptured cyst can be confused clinically with deep vein thrombosis 
or cellulitis, and these conditions can even coexist [10]. Generally, 
it 
is difficult to consider a primary diagnosis of a TB cyst in a soft  
tissue periarticular joint mass. We therefore report that in the case 
of our patient, the TKA was necessary due to a failure to accelerate 
the advancement of knee joint destruction after the cyst excision and 
treatment with anti-TB drugs.
Acknowledgement
This research did not receive any specific grant from funding 
agencies in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors. The 
patient agreed to his data being submitted for publication.
References
1. SM Tuli. Tuberculosis of the Skeletal System: Bone, Joints, Spine and 
Bursal Sheaths. 3rd ed. New Delhi: Jaypee Brothers Medical Publishers; 
2004.
2. Bianco G, Paris A, Venditti M, Calderini C, Anzivino C, Serra P. [Popliteal 
(Baker's) cyst in a patient with tubercular arthritis. Report of a case and 
review of the literature]. Recenti Prog Med. 2001;92(11):663-6.
3. Kramer S.B. LSHS, Abramson SB. Tuberculosis. 2nd ed. Philadelphia, PA: 
Lippincott Williams& Wilkins; 2004. 577-586.
4. Krawzak HW, Scherf FG, Bong J, Hohlbach G. [Baker's cyst in 
osteoarticular tuberculosis of the knee joint]. Dtsch Med Wochenschr. 
1994;119(46):1579-82.
5. Herman AM, Marzo JM. Popliteal cysts: a current review. Orthopedics. 
2014;37(8):e678-84.
6. Labropoulos N, Shifrin DA, Paxinos O. New insights into the development 
of popliteal cysts. Br J Surg. 2004;91(10):1313-8.
7. TD McHugh. Tuberculosis: Diagnosis and Treatment (Advances in 
Molecular and Cellular Microbiology). 1st ed. Oxfordshire, UK: CABI; 
2013.
8. Kulshrestha A, Misra RN, Agarwal P, Gupta D. Magnetic resonance 
appearance of tuberculosis of the knee joint with ruptured Baker's cyst. 
Australas Radiol. 1995;39(1):80-3.
9. Cantini F, Nannini C, Niccoli L, Iannone F, Delogu G, Garlaschi G, et 
al. Guidance for the management of patients with latent tuberculosis 
infection requiring biologic therapy in rheumatology and dermatology 
clinical practice. Autoimmun Rev. 2015;14(6):503-9.
10. Weiner SR, Fan P. Popliteal cyst involvement with gonococcal arthritis-
dermatitis syndrome. Sex Transm Dis. 1983;10(3):141-3.

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Auwerda JJA* and Ellis EL
metadata.title: Positive Impact of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin Administration on the Exercise Capacity in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy

page_content:
1
Annals of Clinical Case Reports
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2740
Positive Impact of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin 
Administration on the Exercise Capacity in a Patient with 
Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
Case Report
Published: 03 May, 2025
Abstract
Hydroxocobalamin is used to treat patients with symptomatic vitamin B12 deficiency. The British 
National Formulary recommends initiating treatment with alternate-day intramuscular (i.m.) 
administration of 1000 mcg hydroxocobalamin, maintaining this regimen until all symptoms have 
resolved or no longer improve. A subset of patients with B12 deficiency requires high-frequency 
i.m. supplementation to remain symptom-free, but the mechanism behind this need is clarification. 
We describe a patient who showed maximum improvement in symptoms and exercise capacity 
only with daily administration. Reducing the injection frequency worsened symptoms and 
objectively decreased exercise capacity. More research is needed to elucidate why some patients 
with symptomatic B12 deficiency require high frequency i.m. supplementation and to determine the 
best individualized regimen for such individuals.
Auwerda JJA* and Ellis EL
Bijlmerdreef 1169-4, 1103 TT Amsterdam, Netherlands
OPEN ACCESS
 *Correspondence:
JJA Auwerda, Bijlmerdreef 1169-4, 1103 
TT Amsterdam, Netherlands,
E-mail: hajo@b12nederland.com
Received Date: 17 Apr 2025
Accepted Date: 02 May 2025
Published Date: 03 May 2025
Citation: 
Auwerda JJA, Ellis EL. Positive Impact 
of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin 
Administration on the Exercise Capacity 
in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory 
Demyelinating Polyneuropathy. Ann 
Clin Case Rep. 2025; 10: 2740.
ISSN: 2474-1655.
Copyright © 2025 Auwerda JJA. This 
is an open access article distributed 
under the Creative Commons Attribution 
License, which permits unrestricted 
use, distribution, and reproduction in 
any medium, provided the original work 
is properly cited.
Introduction
Vitamin B12 (cobalamin, abbreviated B12) deficiency is common. Symptoms typically develop 
gradually over several months or even years and overlap with many other common disorders [1]. 
Although the classic presentation of deficiency is megaloblastic anemia caused by autoimmune 
pernicious anemia [2,3], the majority of B12-deficient individuals in Western countries present 
with neurological or cognitive symptoms rather than anemia or enlarged red blood cells [4]. These 
complaints include neurocognitive symptoms such as 'brain fog', memory problems, cognitive 
impairment, insomnia, headaches (especially migraines), and learning difficulties. The most 
prominent neurologic symptoms are peripheral tingling sensations ('pins and needles'), numbness, 
nerve pain, muscle weakness, poor balance, dizziness, and ringing in the ears. General symptoms 
include fatigue, weight loss, diarrhea, symptoms related to other nutrient deficiencies, and 
sometimes darkening of the skin [4].
Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (CIDP) is a rare, immune-mediated 
disorder in which an abnormal immune response causes damage to the protective covering of 
nerves and to the nerve fibers themselves. The exact cause of CIDP remains unknown [5]. Patients 
experience progressive weakness, impaired sensory function in the legs and arms, loss of deep 
tendon reflexes, and general symptoms like fatigue. CIDP is a long-term condition with a variable 
course that can be relapsing-remitting, stepwise progressive, or gradually progressive [5].
Guidelines from the European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve Society 
(EFNS/PNS) provide recommendations for CIDP treatments, aiming to reduce symptoms and, 
if possible, maintain long-term remission [6]. Treatment with intravenous immunoglobulin 
(IVIG) or corticosteroids is recommended for patients with moderate to severe disability. If 
IVIG and corticosteroids are ineffective, plasma exchange should be considered. If the response 
is inadequate or the required drug maintenance dose is high, combination treatments with either 
immunosuppressants or immunomodulators should be considered [5,6]. However, due to lack of 
evidence, there are no recommendations for long-term management.
We describe a 66-year-old man diagnosed with chronic inflammatory demyelinating 
polyneuropathy (CIDP), whose symptoms worsened in parallel with vitamin B12 deficiency.
Case Presentation
A male patient in his 60s was initially diagnosed in his 40s with Guillain-Barré Syndrome, which

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Auwerda JJA* and Ellis EL
metadata.title: Positive Impact of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin Administration on the Exercise Capacity in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy

page_content:
2
Auwerda JJA, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2740
caused paralysis from his neck down. His breathing was not affected. 
He was treated with two series of 5-day IVIG courses that restored 
most functionality, but at such a low level that he required clinical 
rehabilitation for 8 months, followed by outpatient rehabilitation for 
almost two years. During that period, he experienced several relapses 
that were also treated with 5-day IVIG courses.
After a significant relapse, he was referred to a university hospital 
for a second opinion. His diagnosis was changed to CIDP, later revised 
to CIDP with acute onset. The Professor who performed the second 
opinion stated that he found a mild polyneuropahty togehter with 
clear axonal damage (EMG) but no signs of demyelinisation. In the 
following years, CIDP was treated with IVIG, initially at three-week 
intervals. Over time, the decline after infusion accelerated, resulting 
in shorter intervals between infusions. Eventually, even two infusions 
per week were inadequate to counter the decline, and this treatment 
was discontinued.
The patient was then given azathioprine, but this had no effect. 
He was again referred to the university hospital for another opinion. 
He was initially treated with five days of plasma exchange, but 
without effect. Subsequently, he started prednisolone treatment. 
After an initial improvement lasting two to three weeks, there was 
no further improvement in clinical symptoms, so the treatment was 
discontinued after several months.
The patient then went through a moderate period during 
which he felt very weak yet was diagnosed as being in remission. A 
new episode of inpatient rehabilitation for 8 months, followed by 
outpatient therapy for over a year, resulted in a slight functional 
improvement. However, he again experienced substantial worsening 
of his symptoms, especially muscle weakness.
His CIDP was presumed to be relapsing, and IVIG was restarted. 
He began using a pedometer to objectively measure his exercise 
capacity, and IVIG treatment clearly improved this (Figure 1, blue 
line), but not to the level he had achieved in previous years.
Subsequently, laboratory tests revealed a vitamin B12 deficiency 
in addition to his CIDP. The total serum B12 concentration was 
85 pmol/L (160-700 pmol/l), and methylmalonic acid was 390 
nmol/L (<350 nmol/l), reflecting a functional B12 deficiency. He 
had no anemia (Hb 14.5 g/dl, MCV 91 fl). The upper digestive tract 
examination was not performed.
Because he regularly consumed animal products, it was concluded 
that he had B12 malabsorption because his antibodies against 
parietal cells were positive. He promptly started intramuscular (i.m.) 
hydroxocobalamin injections of 1000 mcg, three times per week, in 
addition to the weekly IVIG. This significantly improved his condition 
(Figure 1, orange line). He used a pedometer to measure the time it 
took him to cover a certain distance to objectively assess his exercise 
capacity. The combination of weekly IVIG and B12 injections three 
times per week enabled him to cover 2.6 km in 33 minutes on average.
Because he experienced that the effect of the B12 injections on his 
clinical condition was rather short-lasting, he switched to daily B12 
injections. This stabilized his condition throughout the week (Figure 
1, grey line, startup phase) and, over the course of a couple of weeks, 
even lessened the standard decline following IVIG (Figure 1, yellow 
line, steady phase).
To determine whether it was necessary to continue this high 
frequency of B12 injections, which is not supported by current 
medical guidelines, he deliberately reduced the injection frequency to 
three times weekly and even skipped injections for a whole week. This 
immediately resulted in a considerable drop in his exercise capacity, 
with a lap time of 41 minutes in the week without a B12 injection. 
Furthermore, this also caused an increase in coordination disorders, 
muscle tremors, and sensory impairment in the feet. After restarting 
daily B12 injections, his exercise capacity gradually recovered.
Investigations 
When his symptoms worsened despite IVIG treatment, routine 
blood tests showed no specific abnormalities. Liver enzymes were 
normal, as were kidney function and C-reactive protein. Serum 
B12 concentration was 85 pmol/L, and methylmalonic acid was 390 
nmol/L. Homocysteine was not measured. Thyroid function was 
normal. Tests for antibodies against stomach lining cells, intrinsic 
factor, and thyroid peroxidase were not performed.
Outcome and Follow-Up
Treatment with high-frequency i.m. hydroxocobalamin 
injections together with IVIG administration resulted in a 
considerable reduction of symptoms and improvement in exercise 
capacity. During a trial of reducing and temporarily stopping high-
frequency B12 injections, the patient clearly experienced worsening 
of symptoms and exercise capacity, which was completely reversed 
after restarting daily B12 administration.
Discussion
Once B12 deficiency due to B12 malabsorption has been 
diagnosed, treatment consists of i.m. hydroxocobalamin injections, 
which should be maintained for life [4]. Most guidelines suggest that 
the initial loading is with 1000 mcg hydroxocobalamin injections 
twice a week or on alternate days until all symptoms have resolved or 
do not improve further. Subsequently, the frequency of the injections 
is gradually reduced, and in most patients, the clinical improvement 
and absence of complaints can be maintained with one injection of 
1000 mcg every four weeks to two months.
In The Netherlands, drug therapy guidelines recommend 
administering hydroxocobalamin 1000 mcg once or twice a week for 
up to two years in cases of neurological symptoms or abnormalities. 
However, it is unclear which neurological symptoms or abnormalities 
require such intensive treatment and how long-term treatment should 
be continued after the initial two years. It may take several months or 
even years for neurological symptoms to resolve completely. Clinical 
evidence suggests that with longer duration and more severe B12 
deficiency, neurological symptoms are more likely to persist to some 
degree [4]. People often continue to experience mild neurological 
symptoms such as poor memory, impaired concentration, and fatigue 
even after 'adequate' B12 replacement [1,8,9].
Many people with B12 deficiency report that the prescribed 
frequency of B12 injections in the maintenance phase is insufficient to 
manage symptoms [10,11]. They experience recurrence or worsening 
of symptoms when the interval between injections is extended or 
extended too quickly, and report that continuation of frequent i.m. 
injections of hydroxocobalamin, ranging from twice-weekly to once 
every 3-4 weeks [12], is needed to remain symptom-free.
It is not clear why certain patients require more frequent 
treatment. It is also unknown why hydroxocobalamin administered 
daily, or every other day may contribute to improving symptoms.

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Auwerda JJA* and Ellis EL
metadata.title: Positive Impact of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin Administration on the Exercise Capacity in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy

page_content:
3
Auwerda JJA, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2740
When administered twice-weekly, serum B12 concentrations are 
high, although within the first 48 hours after i.m. injection, 70-90% 
of B12 is excreted by the kidneys and lost in the urine. There is no 
literature to support the fact that in some patients the benefit of an 
B12 injection can be so shortlived that is why we submit this case 
report. Manny doctors have the misconception that B12 deficiency is 
ruled out in patients without anemia which in turn has led to delayed 
diagnosis notably in people presenting solely with neurological 
symptoms. There is, however, literature supporting the fact that 
some patients may experience recurrence or worsening of symptoms 
when the interval between injections is extended or extended too 
quickly, and they report that continuation of frequent intramuscular 
hydroxocobalamin injections, vaying between twice-weekly and 
once every three to four weeks, is needed to remain asymptomatic. 
Why certain patients require more frequent treatment is not yet 
understood.
Cobalamin is taken up into central and peripheral nervous tissue 
through the CD320 receptor [13], but recent studies have suggested 
that an alternative, as yet unidentified mechanism for neural B12 
uptake also exists [14]. CD320 is a complex receptor; it features an 
N-terminal, extracellular fragment comprising two Low-density 
Lipoprotein Receptor Type A (LDLR-A) domains, separated by an 
epidermal growth factor (EGF) homology domain. The exact function 
of this domain has not yet been established, but it has been suggested 
that it plays a crucial role in the binding of transcobalamin to the 
receptor [15]. CD320 also contains a single transmembrane helix and 
a C-terminal cell interior region involved in complex internalization.
is no data on the effects of specific genetic variations in the genes 
encoding the different protein domains on CD320-transcobalamin 
binding and uptake of cobalamin into the cell. The CD320 knockout 
mouse develops cobalamin deficiency in the nervous system, leading 
to loss of nerve myelin and inflammation [16]. A recent study showed 
the presence of anti-transcobalamin receptor antibodies in a disease 
called cutaneous arteritis [17]. Theoretically, such antibodies could 
interfere with transcobalamin binding to the receptor and subsequent 
uptake, altering the need for B12 supplementation. We urgently 
need human studies exploring the effects of structural and post-
translational changes on the CD320 receptor on the need for high-
frequency B12 administration and more information on the role of 
alternative neural B12 uptake in humans.
The effects of B12 on cell metabolism are multifold. It is an 
essential cofactor of methylmalonyl-Coenzyme A mutase in 
mitochondria, which converts methylmalonyl-CoA to succinyl-CoA, 
and plays a role in the breakdown of amino acids and odd-chain 
fatty acids. It also is a cofactor for methionine synthase (MS), which 
catalyzes the transfer of a methyl group from methyltetrahydrofolate 
(MTHF) to homocysteine to form methionine, and contributes to 
DNA methylation and glutathione synthesis. It also affects histone 
modification and the generation of reactive oxygen species. In these 
pathways, there is a complex interaction of B12 with other B-vitamins, 
including vitamins B1, B3, and folate (18). Disturbances in these 
complex networks may play a role in the mitochondrial dysfunction 
evidenced by persistent symptoms and different B12 supplementation 
needs between individuals.
There are some indications in the literature that we may consider 
cobalamin a general nerve-protecting and -regenerating compound. 
Cobalamin may regulate the balance between neurotoxic and nerve 
growth-promoting agents [19,20]. Micronutrients, including vitamin 
B12, might improve nerve function scores in people with type 
2 diabetes [21], but in this study, a mixture of nutrients was used, 
including multivitamins and oral vitamin B12. Another study reported 
that vitamin B12 injections were more effective than nortriptyline in 
the treatment of painful diabetic nerve damage [22]. A 2005 review 
of multiple studies [23] reported that high-dose oral cyanocobalamin 
or methylcobalamin had beneficial effects on symptoms of diabetic 
nerve damage, such as pain and abnormal sensations. In three studies, 
treatment with methylcobalamin also improved automatic nervous 
system symptoms. Effects on vibration perception and electrical 
nerve function measures were inconsistent. However, one review 
found no evidence that the use of oral vitamin B12 supplements is 
associated with improvement in the clinical symptoms of diabetic 
nerve damage [24]. Low central nervous system cobalamin levels 
may even play a role in the development of multiple sclerosis [25,26]. 
Similar observations, and even reports of the beneficial effects of B12 
injection therapy, have been reported in people with chronic fatigue 
syndrome, with and without widespread pain [27,28].
There is evidence that placebo treatments can have significant 
and sustained effects on clinical outcomes in multiple conditions, 
particularly those where emotion and motivation play a central role 
[29]. While a placebo may, on average, improve exercise capacity, a 
recent study of 28 trained cyclists showed that exercise performance 
remained unchanged in the majority of them, while it improved in 
11 and worsened in four [30]. In contrast, most intervention studies 
in heart failure patients found limited to no improvement in exercise 
capacity in the placebo arm [31]. In vitamin B12 deficiency, there is 
no evidence that recovery from severe anemia or normalizing elevated 
methylmalonic acid levels due to hydroxocobalamin injections 
can be regarded as a placebo effect. Yet, when patients' neurologic 
or cognitive complaints improve through injection therapy, some 
doctors consider this to be a placebo effect. This patient conducted a 
study with himself as the only subject. This type of study is increasingly 
accepted for evaluating the effects of treatment, especially in rare 
diseases. The objective deterioration of his exercise capacity when 
reducing the frequency and skipping the B12 injections suggests a 
minimal role for a possible placebo effect.
There are no well-designed studies of hydroxocobalamin 
injections in patients with neurologic symptoms caused by vitamin 
B12 deficiency to conform or reject the placebo effect. Clearly there is a 
need for well-conducted double-blind, randomized studies in patients 
with vitamin B12 deficiency who report the benefit of continued 
frequent hydroxocobalamin injections vs oral supplementation. The 
biomarkers for determining a functional vitamin B12 deficiency 
normalize more rapidly than the improvement or reversal of 
(neurological) symptoms. Additionally, symptoms may reappear 
without changes in biomarker status. Therefore, these biomarkers 
cannot be used to determine that the vitamin B12 deficiency has been 
treated optimally.
In summary, we discuss a patient with chronic inflammatory 
demyelinating polyneuropathy who developed B12 deficiency during 
his disease. Long-term daily hydroxocobalamin administration 
has proved necessary to reduce symptoms and maximize exercise 
capacity. The biological mechanism behind such high-frequency 
treatment needs to be elucidated.
Learning Points/Take Home Messages
•	 Vitamin B12 deficiency may  cause considerable

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Auwerda JJA* and Ellis EL
metadata.title: Positive Impact of High-Frequency Hydroxocobalamin Administration on the Exercise Capacity in a Patient with Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy

page_content:
4
Auwerda JJA, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2740
neurological and/or cognitive symptoms.
•	 The British National Formulary provides instructions to 
commence i.m. supplementation therapy with alternate-day dosing 
of 1000 mcg hydroxocobalamin until all symptoms have disappeared 
or do not improve further.
•	 Long-term high-frequency B12 administration may be 
warranted in people whose symptoms reappear when injection 
frequency is reduced.
•	 Our patient showed sustained improvement in symptoms 
and exercise capacity while injecting 1000 mcg B12 i.m. daily.
Patient’s Perspective
After another severe relapse in 2016 due to my CIDP condition, 
I returned to outpatient rehabilitation. Progress was slow and my 
condition was very poor compared to my situation before the relapse. 
Blood tests showed a B12 deficiency but my physician was not very 
impressed with the test results and told me the standard treatment of 
5 weeks B12 injections would be sufficient.
In conversations with fellow patients, they urged me to have a 
second opinion. During that specialist examination, it was determined 
that I had a chronic B12 deficiency. Looking back, I think it may have 
been present for many years.
After starting the B12 injections, my rehabilitation progress 
increased and after a couple of months I was released from therapy. 
From experience during a previous rehabilitation, I knew how 
important exercise was. That is why I went for a walk every day. As 
a researcher, I wanted to objectify my results using a pedometer. I 
noticed that the day after a B12 shot I was stronger and faster than the 
other day, so after a while I took a B12 shot every day. This eased my 
loss of strength. I was stable all week and more importantly after a few 
weeks the decline after a IVIG became less severe, what a welcome 
result!
Now, seven years later, I still experience a huge advantage benefit 
taking B12 every day. Friends and professional physicians suggested 
that the effect may have been due to a placebo effect. Even when if it 
that were true, I would gladly accept that outcome. Why throw away 
a cheap mechanism that works without side effects? But in this case, 
I am sure there is no placebo effect. Why? Because every now and 
then I felt less strength and energy, and when I checked (afterwards), 
it turned out that I had forgotten my B12 injection from the day 
before. So, I am fully convinced that B12 injections are essential to 
my wellbeing. No one likes having needles in your skin, but I do like 
it because of the positive effects.
References
1. Green R, Allen LH, Bjorke-Monsen AL, Brito A, Gueant JL, Miller JW, et 
al. Vitamin B12 deficiency. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2017;3:17040.
2. Devalia V, Hamilton MS, Molloy AM, British Committee for Standards 
in H. Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of cobalamin and folate 
disorders. Br J Haematol. 2014;166(4):496-513.
3. Mohamed M, Thio J, Thomas RS, Phillips J. Pernicious anaemia. BMJ. 
2020;369:m1319.
4. Wolffenbuttel BHR, Wouters H, Heiner-Fokkema MR, van der Klauw 
MM. The Many Faces of Cobalamin (Vitamin B(12)) Deficiency. Mayo 
Clin Proc Innov Qual Outcomes. 2019;3(2):200-14.
5. Stino AM, Naddaf E, Dyck PJ, Dyck PJB. Chronic inflammatory 
demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy-Diagnostic pitfalls and treatment 
approach. Muscle Nerve. 2021;63(2):157-69.
6. Van den Bergh PY, Hadden RD, Bouche P, Cornblath DR, Hahn A, Illa 
I, et al. European Federation of Neurological Societies/Peripheral Nerve

metadata.author: Veronica Iascone1
metadata.title: Helicobacter pylori Negative Autoimmune Atrophic Gastritis and Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT) Lymphoma of the Stomach: Case Report and Systematic Review of the Literature

page_content:
1
Annals of Clinical Case Reports
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2747
Helicobacter pylori Negative Autoimmune Atrophic 
Gastritis and Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT) 
Lymphoma of the Stomach: Case Report and Systematic 
Review of the Literature
Case Report
Published: 26 May, 2025
Abstract
Autoimmune atrophic gastritis (AAG) is a chronic inflammation with atrophy of oxyntic mucosa 
due to anti-parietal cell and/or anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. Autoimmune atrophic gastritis 
is a preneoplastic condition that predisposes to type I neuroendocrine tumours and gastric 
adenocarcinoma. Guidelines recommend endoscopic follow-up of patients with AAG for the early 
diagnosis of gastric malignancies. There is evidence that some autoimmune diseases may predispose 
to the development of MALT lymphoma. In this study, we reported the first case of Helicobacter 
(H.) pylori negative AAG who developed a gastric MALT lymphoma. No other cases were identified 
by a systematic review of the literature.
Veronica Iascone1, Elton Dajti1, Lara Mencarini1, Antonietta D’Errico1,2, Claudio Agostinelli1,3, 
Pier Luigi Zinzani1,4, Marianna Gentilini1,4, Franco Bazzoli1 and Rocco Maurizio Zagari1,5* 
1Department of Medical and Surgical Sciences, University of Bologna, Bologna, Italy
2Pathology Unit, IRCCS – Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
3Haematopatology Unit, IRCCS – Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
4Istituto di Ematologia “L. e A. Seragnoli”, IRCCS Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
5Gastroesophageal disease Unit, IRCCS – Azienda Ospedaliero-Universitaria di Bologna, Bologna, Italy
OPEN ACCESS

Prof. Rocco Maurizio Zagari, 
Department of Medical and Surgical 
Sciences, Gastroesophageal Disease 
Unit, IRCCS – Azienda Ospedaliero-
Universitaria di Bologna, University of 
Bologna, Via Massarenti, 9. 40138. 
Bologna. Italy, Tel: +393341705589;
E-mail: roccomaurizio.zagari@unibo.it
Received Date: 09 May 2025
Accepted Date: 23 May 2025
Published Date: 26 May 2025
Citation: 
Iascone V, Dajti E, Mencarini L, 
D’Errico A, Agostinelli C, Zinzani PL, 
et al. Helicobacter pylori Negative 
Autoimmune Atrophic Gastritis and 
Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue 
(MALT) Lymphoma of the Stomach: 
Case Report and Systematic Review 
of the Literature. Ann Clin Case Rep. 
2025; 10: 2747.
ISSN: 2474-1655.
Copyright © 2025 Rocco Maurizio 
Zagari. This is an open access 
article distributed under the Creative 
Commons Attribution License, which 
permits unrestricted use, distribution, 
and reproduction in any medium, 
provided the original work is properly 
cited.
Introduction
Autoimmune atrophic gastritis (AAG) is a chronic condition characterized by presence of 
atrophy in the oxyntic mucosa due to anti-parietal cell and/or anti-intrinsic factor antibodies. The 
immune system attacks and damage the oxyntic mucosa leading to chronic gastritis and destruction 
or loss of parietal cells [1]. This condition is associated with others autoimmune disorders, especially 
type 1 diabetes and autoimmune thyroiditis [2]. Autoimmune atrophic gastritis is a preneoplastic 
condition that predisposes to development of several malignancies, including type I neuroendocrine 
tumours and gastric adenocarcinoma. Whether AAG also predisposes to the development of gastric 
mucosa associated lymphoid tissue (MALT) lymphoma is not clear. It is well known that gastric 
MALT lymphoma usually develops in the background of H. pylori positive chronic gastritis [3]. In 
this study, we reported a case of H. pylori negative AAG who developed a gastric MALT lymphoma.
Case Presentation 
A 51-year-old female suffering from autoimmune thyroiditis underwent serological screening 
for other autoimmunity diseases, including autoimmune gastritis and hepatitis. She resulted 
positive for both anti-parietal cells and anti-intrinsic factor antibodies, in addition to anti-nucleus 
and anti-mitochondrial antibodies. Therefore, in May 2018 she underwent high-definition white 
light gastroscopy with chromoendoscopy by narrow band imaging (NBI). No visible neoplastic 
suspicious lesions were detected; endoscopic findings were ipo-atrophic mucosal pattern in the 
corpus and mucosal erythema in the antrum. Random biopsies of gastric mucosa were taken 
according to the Updated Sydney System, i.e. two biopsies from the antrum, one from the incisura 
angularis and two from the corpus. Histological examination showed moderate atrophic gastritis 
with pseudopyloric and intestinal metaplasia and linear hyperplasia of enterochromaffin-like cells 
in the corpus and superficial non-atrophic gastritis with G cells iperplasia in the antrum (Figure 
1). Helicobacter pylori  were not found either in the antrum or in the corpus. Therefore, she was 
diagnosed with H. pylori negative AAG. At the blood test, haemoglobin, cobalamin, vitamin D and 
iron levels were normal, while serum gastrin and chromogranin were abnormally high. Serum IgG

page_content:
2
Veronica Iascone, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Surgical Sciences   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2747
antibodies anti-H. pylori were negatives suggesting the absence of 
a past H. pylori infection. The patient accepted to participate to the 
multicenter, observational study “the autoimmune gastritis in Italy- 
AG-ItaReg” approved by the Ethical Committee of Area Vasta Emilia 
Centro, Bologna, Italy. The AG-ItaReg is a national prospective 
study aimed to create an online data-base registering all patients 
diagnosed with autoimmune gastritis in the participants centers 
in Italy. The main outcome of this study is to assess predictors and 
incidence of gastric malignancies in patients with AAG. Thus, for 
each patient enrolled demographic, clinic, endoscopic and histologic 
characteristics along with the results of laboratory tests are collected 
and endoscopic follow-up is performed. 
At the first follow-up endoscopy performed in November 
2020, an area of mucosal erythema in the greater curvature of the 
corpus was found. During endoscopy, targeted biopsies from the 
area of mucosal erythema and random biopsies from the antrum 
and corpus were taken. The histological evaluation of targeted 
biopsies revealed a severe infiltrate of lymphoid elements arranged 
in aggregates or dispersed in the lamina propria as for the presence 
of gastric MALT lymphoma, while random biopsies confirmed the 
corpus-limited atrophic gastritis without H. pylori infection. At the 
immunohistochemical stain the diagnosis of gastric MALT lymphoma 
derived from peripheral B lymphocytes of the marginal area was 
confirmed (Figure 2). Lymphoid population was predominantly of 
type B, Cyclin D (CD) 20 and IRTA positives and CD1, CD5, CD10, 
CD23 and MNDA negatives, with low growth fraction/MIB1 and 
kappa/lambda ratio not clearly unbalanced. 
In December 2020, the patient was referred to the Haematological 
Unit of our hospital for the staging and treatment of gastric MALT 
lymphoma. She underwent 
13C-urea breath test (UBT) for H. pylori, 
endoscopic ultrasound sonography (EUS) of the stomach, neck-
thoraco-abdominal computerized tomography (CT) scan and osteo-
medullary biopsy. As expected, the UBT was negative confirming the 
absence of H. pylori infection. The EUS showed a minimal thickening 
of the mucosal layer in the area involved by marginal lymphoma and 
no peri-gastric lymphadenopathy. No significant lymphadenopathy 
was detected at the CT scan and the bone marrow biopsy resulted 
negative. 
Haematologists decided to treat the patient with anti-CD20 
monoclonal antibody (rituximab), but the treatment was delayed 
due to the COVID-19 pandemy for the high risk of infection related 
Figure 1: Histological features of autoimmune atrophic gastritis. Oxyntic mucosa with diffuse pseudopyloric metaplasia (Hematoxylin-eosin stain, 10 x magnification) 
and linear hyperplasia of enterochromaffin-like cells (chromogranin A staining, 20 x magnification).
Figure 2: Histological features of gastric MALT lymphoma. Diffuse proliferation of small/medium sized lymphocytes with clear cytoplasm (Giemsa stain, 200 x 
magnification), which strongly expressed CD20 at immunoistochemical investigation (200 x magnification).

page_content:
3
Veronica Iascone, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Surgical Sciences   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2747
to immunosuppression. Thus, an intensive clinical, haematological 
and endoscopic follow-up every three months was undertaken. In 
this period, the patient remained asymptomatic, blood test resulted 
normal, except for gastrin and chromogranin, and endoscopic, 
histologic and EUS findings did not change. Histological examination 
of biopsy specimens taken during follow-up endoscopies confirmed 
the diagnosis of gastric MALT lymphoma.
The treatment was started in September 2022 with 375 mg/
m
2 intravenous rituximab every week for four consecutive weeks. 
At the endoscopic follow-up performed three months after the end 
of treatment, the mucosal erythema in the corpus disappeared and 
the histological examination of showed a complete regression of 
gastric MALT lymphoma; at the 6-month follow-up, endoscopic and 
histological findings did not change. Unfortunately, at the 12-month 
follow-up, albeit there were not endoscopic lesions, the histological 
examination of random biopsies showed a relapse of gastric MALT 
lymphoma in the corpus. At this time, the patient did not report 
either symptoms or abnormalities at the blood test, apart from those 
related to the autoimmune atrophic gastritis (i.e. increase of gastrin 
and chromogranin). She underwent again 
13C-UBT for H. pylori, 
EUS, CT scan and osteo-medullary biopsy that resulted all negatives. 
She underwent again 13C-UBT for H. pylori, EUS of the stomach, 
Figure 3: Flow chart of systematic search of the literature.
neck-thoraco-abdominal CT scan and osteo-medullary biopsy that 
resulted all negatives. The fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission 
tomography (PET-FDG) showed only a mild and diffuse uptake 
in the gastric wall with standardized update value (SUV) of 3.5. 
Considering the limited disease gastric MALT lymphoma and the 
lack of treatment criteria, the patient has been maintained only in 
endoscopic follow-up. 
Discussion
Autoimmune atrophic gastritis is a preneoplastic condition 
that can potentially lead to neuroendocrine tumours and gastric 
adenocarcinoma, while the association with MALT lymphoma 
is not clear. We reported here a patient with AAG who developed 
a gastric MALT lymphoma without evidence of present or past H. 
pylori infection. We performed a systematic review of the literature 
following the recommendations of the Preferred Reporting Items for 
Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses [4] to assess whether AAG 
can predispose to the development of gastric MALT lymphoma. 
We searched PubMed, Embase, Scopus, and the Cochrane Library 
databases up to 15 February 2025 using the keywords “autoimmune”, 
“gastritis”, “mucosa associated lymphoid tissue”, “MALT”, and 
“lymphoma cell B”, without restricting for language and type of 
publication (Table 1). Studies were included if they reported the

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Veronica Iascone1
metadata.title: Helicobacter pylori Negative Autoimmune Atrophic Gastritis and Mucosa-Associated Lymphoid Tissue (MALT) Lymphoma of the Stomach: Case Report and Systematic Review of the Literature

page_content:
4
Veronica Iascone, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Surgical Sciences   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2747
development of gastric MALT lymphoma in patients with AAG. 
We excluded studies with concomitant H. pylori infection as this 
bacterium is the main cause of gastric MALT lymphoma. Electronic 
search identified 519 records after duplicates were removed, of which 
22 articles were assessed for eligibility. Of these, only one reported 
the development of gastric MALT lymphoma in one patient with 
AAG [5]. However, because of the concomitant presence of H. pylori 
infection, the article was excluded. Therefore, no article met the 
inclusion criteria and was included in the review (Figure 3). 
Indeed, this is the first case-report describing the development 
of gastric MALT lymphoma in the background of H. pylori negative 
AAG. Chronic gastritis can arise from H. pylori infection or may start 
as an autoimmune condition. In both scenarios, persistent antigenic 
stimulation leading to chronic inflammation is associated with 
an increased risk of malignancies [6,7] . In addition, autoimmune 
diseases can predispose to development of MALT lymphoma; there 
is evidence that Sjogren syndrome and autoimmune thyroiditis 
are associated with an increased risk of salivary gland and thyroid 
MALT lymphoma, respectively [8]. In autoimmune diseases, the 
ongoing inflammation and antigenic stimulation could stimulate 
the growth and clonal expansion of B or T cells, elevating the risk 
of genetic anomalies and consequent lymphoma development [9] . 
Furthermore, there are reports of autoimmune conditions emerging 
during lymphoma progression suggesting a mutual relationship 
between autoimmunity and lymphoid tumours [10]. There is evidence 
that about 10% of patients with gastric MALT lymphoma are positive 
for parietal cells antibodies, albeit in absence of atrophic gastritis 
[11]. However, the biological mechanisms linking autoimmune 
diseases and lymphoma remain largely elusive and require further 
investigation.
Conclusion 
In conclusion, our study suggests that AAG can predispose to the 
development of gastric MALT lymphoma, which is in line with other 
autoimmune diseases. Our findings further support the guideline 
recommendation to perform endoscopic surveillance in patients with 
AAG for the secondary prevention of gastric malignancies. Indeed, 
large prospective cohort studies with a long-term follow-up are 
needed to clarify the relationship between AAG and gastric MALT 
lymphoma.

metadata.title: Thyroid Abscess

page_content:
1
Annals of Clinical Case Reports
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2770
Thyroid Abscess
Case Report
Published: 17 Sep, 2025
Abstract
The thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to its abundant lymphatic drainage, dual 
blood supply, encapsulation and high iodin concentration. 
Suppurative thyroiditis is an uncommon type of thyroiditis, including thyroid abscess, accounts for 
only 0.7% to 1% of all thyroid diseases. 
Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequently isolated organism. Streptococcus, pneumococcus, 
salmonella, klebsiella and rarely mycobacterium, are examples of bacteria that are involved in many 
AST. 
A 42-year-old healthy female with 3 days history of fever and painful anterior neck swelling 
associated with odynophagia with no history of neck trauma. 
Examination showed anterior neck swelling in thyroid region, firm and tender and erythema over 
the overlying skin. No clinical lymphadenopathy was detected. Throat examination with fiberscope 
was normal. White blood cell count was high with neutrophilia, increased erythrocyte sedimentation 
rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP) .
Ultrasonography thyroid showed enlarged right thyroid lobe with 2cm hypoechoic nodule. 
Antibiotics (ceftriaxone, flucloxacillin intravenous and clindamycin tablets), propranolol tablets, 
recommended by endocrinologist, dexamethasone intravenous. 
By day 10 after improvement on antibiotics, unexpectedly the patient became febrile clinically ill, 
with rapid progression of a growing mass on the right side of her neck and high WBCs and high 
CRP. The computed tomography with contrast showed a notable enlargement of the right thyroid 
lobe with abscess formation. 
Under general anaesthesia, 30 ml of pus was drained. Streptococcus constellatus (milleri) was 
isolated that showed resistance to clindamycin and sensitivity to penicillin. Meropenem intravenous 
was applied according to microbiologist consultation for two weeks. 6 weeks follow up showed 
Interval ultrasonic resolution of the right thyroid abscess, no pathological nodule was detected, with 
normal thyroid function test.
Alaqeab E, Elghobashy M*, Matin A and Almanassra A
Department of ENT and Head and Neck, University Hospital Limerick, co. limerick, Ireland

Introduction
•	 The	thyroid	gland	is	inherently	resistant	to	infection	due	to	its	abundant	lymphatic	drainage,	
dual	blood	supply,	encapsulation	and	high	iodin	concentration.
•	 Suppurative	 thyroiditis	 is	 an	 uncommon	 type	 of	 thyroiditis.	 Suppurative	 thyroiditis,	
including	thyroid	abscess,	accounts	for	only	0.7%	to	1%	of	all	thyroid	diseases.
•	 Staphylococcus	 aureus	 is	 the	 most	 frequently	 isolated	 organism.	 Streptococcus,	
pneumococcus,	salmonella,	klebsiella	and	rarely	mycobacterium,	are	examples	of	bacteria	
that	are	involved	in	many	AST.
•	 Symptoms	of	acute	thyroiditis	can	typically	include	fever,	pain	in	the	neck,	and	painful	neck	
lump.
•	 Combination	of	clinical	findings	and	diagnostic	imaging	is	used	to	confirm	the	diagnosis	
and	the	ultrasound	is	the	first	diagnostic	investigation	of	choice.
•	 Mortality	rate	of	acute	suppurative	thyroiditis	is	3.7%-9%	
•	 AST	management	includes	antibiotics,	needle	aspiration,	incision	and	drainage	partial	or	
total	thyroidectomy.
•	 AST	could	be	complicated	with	thyroid	abscess,	sepsis,	mediastinitis,	airway	compression

Case Presentation
•	 A 42-year-old healthy female with 3 days history of fever and 
painful anterior neck swelling associated with odynophagia.
•	 No history of neck trauma.
•	 There were no signs or symptoms of airway compression.
•	 Clinically she was febrile with temperature (38.7°C), BP 
(120/700 mmHg), PR (90) beat /min and o2 saturation (98) 
% on room air.
•	 Anterior neck swelling in thyroid region, firm and tender and 
erythema over the overlying skin.
•	 No clinical lymphadenopathy was detected
•	 Throat examination with fiberscope was normal.
•	 White blood cell (WBC) counts 18 with neutrophilia, 
increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 55, and 
C-reactive protein (CRP)120.
•	 Ultrasonography thyroid showed enlarged thyroid lobe with 
2cm hypoechoic nodule mimics AST.
•	 Antibiotics (ceftriaxone 2g every 12 hours, flucloxacillin 
intravenous 2g every 6 hours and clindamycin600mg po 
every 6hours), a. tablet propranolol 10mg, recommended 
by endocrinologist, 12 hourly, dexamethasone 8mg mg IV 8 
hourly Figure 1.
•	 By day 10 after improvement on antibiotics, unexpectedly the 
patient became febrile clinically ill, with rapid progression of 
a growing mass on the right side of her neck and high WBC 
and high CRP,
•	 The computed tomography with contrast showed a notable 
enlargement of the right thyroid lobe with abscess ( 5,6 cm*5 
cm*6.9 cm).
•	 Under general anaesthesia. 30 ml of pus was drained 
streptococcus constellatus (milleri) was isolated that showed 
resistance to clindamycin and sensitivity to penicillin.
•	 Meropenem 2g iv 12 hourly according to microbiologist 
consultation for two weeks.
•	 6 weeks follow up showed Interval ultrasonic resolution 
of the right thyroid abscess, no pathological nodule was 
detected, with normal thyroid function test Figure 2A and 
B.
Discussion
•	 Acute suppurative thyroiditis (AST) is a rare and fatal 
emergency thyroid disease that can lead to abscess formation 
as a secondary disease.
•	 Very unlikely in immunocompetent.
•	 The majority of affected patients are under 40 years old, with 
a slight predominance of women. The age of the index patient 
is the same as the usual age of presentation of this condition.
•	 Pre-existing thyroid diseases such as Hashimoto’s thyroiditis 
or thyroid malignancy.
•	 Pyriform sinus fistula is at increased risk of acquiring AST.
•	 Pyriform fistula is very unlikely in this reported case for 
which is commonly in left side and no history of recurrence.
•	 The reported case is considered as de novo thyroiditis.
•	 Most cases involve the left thyroid lobe.
•	 Staphylococcus aureus is the predominant cause.
•	 As in the index case, most patients are euthyroid.
•	 USG serves as first-line imaging modality. Heterogeneous 
parenchymal echotexture, surrounding fluid collection, and 
hypoechoic nodules are commonly observed USG findings in 
patients of AST.
•	 Radiologically guided aspiration drainage for thyroid abscess 
currently more recommended [1-10].
Conclusion
•	 Acute suppurative thyroiditis is a rare thyroid disease in adult.
•	 The mainstay treatment is antibiotic therapy if fails incision 
Figure 1: CT neck with contrast with enlarged right thyroid lobe and 5 cm 
abscess.
 Figure 2A: Day 3, of presentation.
Figure 2B: Week 8, post incision and drainage.

metadata.title: A Novel Mutation in the LMNA Gene-Associated Hereditary Atrioventricular Block

page_content:
1
Annals of Clinical Case Reports
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2745
A Novel Mutation in the LMNA Gene-Associated 
Hereditary Atrioventricular Block
Case Report
Published: 21 May, 2025
Abstract
Background: Abnormalities in the cardiac conduction system can lead to various cardiac conduction 
disorders, including atrioventricular block (AVB). AVB can be classified as hereditary or secondary 
based on its etiology. Despite advancements in gene sequencing, the pathogenic genes and mutation 
sites underlying inherited AVB require further exploration. 
Results: Our investigation identified a novel mutation (NM_ 170707: c.1609-1G>C) within 
the LMNA gene in the proband (IL-2), which is absent in healthy family members. Protein 
electrophoresis and cDNA sequencing indicated that this mutation alters the splicing pattern of the 
LMNA gene, potentially leading to exon 10 skipping.
Conclusion: We have discovered a novel mutation site (NM_170707.4: c.1609-1G>C) within the 
LMNA gene that is closely associated with AVB occurrence among members of a family lineage. The 
findings underscore the importance of genetic factors in AVB pathogenesis.
Keywords: Atrioventricular block, LMNA gene, Whole-exome sequencing, Lineage survey
Liangliang Zhang1#, Jiao Tang1#, Guodu Liu1#, Maohuan Lin2, Xiaoqin Xiao3, Xin Chen1, Feng 
Wang1, Chen Xie1*, Huanji Zhang1* 
1Department of Cardiovascular Medicine, The Eighth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University, Shenzhen, China
2Department of Cardiovascular Medicine, Sun Yat-Sen Memorial Hospital, Sun Yat-Sen University, Guangzhou, 
China
3Center for Molecular Diagnostics, Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University, Guangzhou, China
#Authors contributed equally
OPEN ACCESS
 *Correspondence:
Chen Xie, Department of 
Cardiovascular Medicine, The Eighth 
Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen 
University, Shenzhen, China, Tel: +86 
83982222;
E-mail: xiech26@mail.sysu.edu.cn
Huanji Zhang, Department of 
Cardiovascular Medicine, The Eighth 
Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen 
University, Shenzhen, China,
E-mail: zhanghj65@mail.sysu.edu.cn
Received Date: 06 May 2025
Accepted Date: 20 May 2025
Published Date: 21 May 2025
Citation: 
Zhang L, Tang J, Liu G, Lin M, Xiao X, 
Chen X, et al. A Novel Mutation in the 
LMNA Gene-Associated Hereditary 
Atrioventricular Block. Ann Clin Case 
Rep. 2025; 10: 2745.
ISSN: 2474-1655.

Huanji Zhang. This is an open access 
article distributed under the Creative 
Commons Attribution License, which 
permits unrestricted use, distribution, 
and reproduction in any medium, 
provided the original work is properly 
cited.
Introduction
Atrioventricular block (AVB) is characterized by delayed transmission of electrical impulses 
through the atrioventricular conduction system. The increased susceptibility to AVB observed 
among first-degree relatives of affected individuals suggests a genetic predisposition to its 
development [1]. With the advancement of gene sequencing technologies, a growing number of 
genes associated with cardiac conduction disorders have been identified, regardless of the presence 
of structural cardiac abnormalities. 
In this study, we investigated a three-generation Chinese family with AVB. AVB was the 
predominant clinical manifestation, with no apparent skeletal muscle abnormalities or structural 
signs of dilated cardiomyopathy observed. Through whole-exome sequencing and cDNA analysis, 
we identified a novel LMNA gene mutation (NM_170707.4: c.1609-1G>C) that appears to be closely 
associated with the development of AVB in this family.
Case Presentation
Population
Informed consent was obtained from three generations of family members in a Chinese family 
grappling with hereditary AVB. Approval for this study was obtained from the Ethics Committee 
of the Eighth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University. Figure 1 shows a diagram of the 
family pedigree. Whole-exome sequencing was performed on three family members with AVB, 
along with two immediate family members without AVB. Comprehensive data, including clinical 
characteristics, diagnostic and therapeutic modalities, laboratory data, and extant medical records 
of deceased patients, were meticulously collated.
Gene sequencing and verification
The control group was drawn from the human B37 database of the Novo Genomics Institute 
(Beijing, China). DNA extraction, data quality control, exome capture, and whole-exome sequencing

page_content:
2
Liangliang Zhang, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Cardiovascular Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2745
were conducted by Novo Genomics Institute (Beijing, China). 
Pathogenic mutation sites were subjected to a meticulous four-step 
screening process involving frequency screening, functional region 
screening, qualitative screening of coding region mutations, and 
harmfulness score screening. Subsequently, pathogenic mutation 
sites were scrutinized to discern the dominant pattern across family 
lines. Following screening, mutation sites situated within a splice 
region underwent cDNA sequencing and protein electrophoresis to 
authenticate functional impacts.
Clinical data
At the time of this study, four members of the family (I-1, II-2, II-
3, and II-4) exhibited cardiac conduction disorders. Table 1 delineates 
the clinical features of the affected family members, and Figure 2 
shows the cardiac MRI of the proband (II-2). The proband (II-2) 
presented at the age of 39 with dizziness following physical activity. 
Electrocardiography (ECG) revealed marked bradycardia and third-
degree atrioventricular block (AVB), for which a pacemaker was 
implanted. Her mother (I-1), who had no history of coronary artery 
disease, diabetes, or hypertension, died of heart failure at the age of 59. 
At age 39, her ECG had already shown third-degree AVB, which was 
initially managed conservatively; however, progressive heart failure 
developed following pacemaker implantation. One of the proband’s 
sisters (II-3) experienced dizziness at the age of 35. Her initial 
ECG revealed sinus bradycardia and second-degree type II AVB. 
Further evaluation with echocardiography and cardiac magnetic 
resonance imaging (MRI) demonstrated an atrial septal aneurysm 
and uncoordinated myocardial contractility. Endomyocardial biopsy 
(EMB) showed no significant abnormalities, and she subsequently 
underwent vagal ganglion ablation.Another sister (II-4) was 
diagnosed at the age of 32 after presenting with dizziness. Her initial 
ECG showed sinus arrhythmia and first-degree AVB. One year later, 
repeat ECG revealed sinus arrest and second-degree AVB. Both ECG 
and cardiac MRI failed to reveal structural abnormalities, and she was 
treated with the implantation of a Medtronic A3DR01 pacemaker.
Summary of whole-exome sequencing
Whole-exome sequencing was performed on the proband (II-2), 
her father (I-2), and her sisters (II-3, II-4, and II-5). The sequencing 
samples exhibited an average data volume of 10.52G, with an average 
effective data volume of 99.05%.  The average Q20 reached 98.13%, 
while the average Q30 stood at 94.76%, with an average error rate 
of 0.03%. Within the target region, the average sequencing depth 
amounted to 119.00X, with an average coverage of 99.36%. Table 
2 summarizes the whole-exome sequencing results for this family, 
encompassing a total of 167,296 single-nucleotide polymorphisms 
and indel mutations. The screening process is depicted in Figure 3. A 
Figure 1: Pedigree diagram of a Chinese family affected by AVB.  Normal 
individuals (without AVB) are shown as clear circles (females) or squares 
(males). Affected individuals are shown as solid symbols. The deceased 
individual is indicated by a slash (/). The proband is indicated by an arrow.

Notes:
Raw data (G): the amount of raw sequence data.
Effective (%): the percentage of clean reads filtered for subsequent bioinformatic analysis of the raw data.
Error (%): the average error rate of all bases.
Q20 and Q30 (%): Percentage of bases with Phred values greater than 20 and 30 out of the overall bases calculated separately, respectively.
GC (%): the sum of the number of bases G and C as a percentage of the total number of bases.

this site mutation, whereas the healthy family member (II-5) did 
not. RT-qPCR analysis demonstrated a substantial up-regulation of 
approximately 32.93% (P < 0.05) in the expression of all LMNA gene 
transcriptomes in the blood of the proband (II-2) ( P < 0.05). This

basal septal wall and hypertrophy of trabeculations from the middle to apical segments of the left ventricle (B). Resting perfusion image showing no abnormality

electrophoresis of RT-PCR products. (C) cDNA sequencing results. The mutation c.16091 G>C will cause exon 10 skipping.
novel mutation (NM_ 170707: c.1609-1G>C) within the LMNA gene 
was found to be closely associated with AVB in this family. Notably, 
this mutation site was located within the splice region of exon 10.
Mutation verification

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Liangliang Zhang1#
metadata.title: A Novel Mutation in the LMNA Gene-Associated Hereditary Atrioventricular Block

page_content:
4
Liangliang Zhang, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Cardiovascular Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2745
underscores the significant effect of this gene variation on LMNA 
gene expression. Protein gel electrophoresis and cDNA sequencing 
highlighted that the presence of the LMNA gene NM_170707.4: 
c.1609-1G>C disrupts the splicing pattern of the LMNA gene, 
potentially instigating exon 10 skipping in one allele. This aberrant 
splicing pattern may be the predominant factor contributing to the 
malfunctioning of the LMNA gene.
Discussion
This study identified a heterozygous mutation, c.1609-1G>C 
(exon 10, NM_170707), in the LMNA gene through whole-exome 
sequencing and multiple bioinformatic prediction tools. Located 
within a canonical splice site, this variant is likely to cause exon 
10 skipping, leading to a frameshift and altered protein structure. 
According to the ACMG classification criteria, the variant was 
deemed pathogenic (PVS1, PM2, PP1, PP3), exhibiting dominant 
inheritance and cosegregation within the family. These findings 
strongly implicate this mutation in the pathogenesis of hereditary 
AVB in this pedigree.
The LMNA gene, located on chromosome 1q21.1–21.2, consists 
of 12 exons and encodes type A lamins, key components of the 
nuclear lamina. Alternative splicing of LMNA gives rise to four major 
isoforms: lamin A, lamin C, lamin C2, and lamin AΔ10 [2,3]. Among 
these, lamin A and lamin C are the principal products, generated 
via alternative splicing of exon 10. Lamin A is initially synthesized 
as prelamin A, which undergoes multiple post-translational 
modifications to form the mature protein [4]. Lamin C2, specifically 
expressed in mouse germ cells, plays a specialized role in nuclear 
structural dynamics and chromosome organization during mitosis 
[5,6]. Lamin A and C proteins, which are encoded by the LMNA gene, 
are essential structural proteins within the cell nucleus that are crucial 
for nuclear morphology, DNA replication, and gene expression 
[3]. LMNA gene mutations can precipitate structural or functional 
abnormalities in lamin A and C proteins, thereby disrupting normal 
nuclear functions such as signal transduction and myocardial cell 
structure [2].
 These mutations may disrupt ion channel function and 
ion conduction, manifesting in AVB within the cardiac conduction 
system [7].
Clinically, mutations in LMNA are most commonly associated 
with dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM), heart failure, and rhythm 
disturbances [8]. As a key gene in DCM pathogenesis, LMNA harbors 
a broad spectrum of pathogenic variants. Affected individuals often 
exhibit progressive conduction defects, and some also present with 
skeletal muscle involvement [9,10]. Notably, LMNA mutations 
account for approximately 33% of familial DCM cases with AVB 
and follow an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern [7]. While 
LMNA mutations are often suspected in patients with dilated 
cardiomyopathy (DCM) accompanied by atrioventricular block 
(AVB), their identification is equally important in young patients 
presenting with AVB alone or with only subtle structural cardiac 
changes. In this case, the absence of overt myocardial involvement 
can delay or obscure diagnosis, despite the underlying genetic 
etiology. Early recognition of LMNA-related conduction disease—
even before the onset of significant cardiomyopathy—can enable 
timely intervention, family screening, and longitudinal monitoring 
for progressive cardiac dysfunction.
Within the family evaluated in this study, all affected members 
exhibited singular AVB without observable structural changes in the 
heart. The pathogenic effects of the LMNA gene mutation appear 
to initiate in the conduction cells of the atrioventricular node or 
His bundle; the subsequent effects in cardiac cells lead to atrial and 
ventricular dilatation, ultimately resulting in heart failure [11]. A 
recent UK-based cohort study involving 1,167 individuals with 
LMNA mutations reported a mean age of disease onset at 67 years 
[12]. In contrast, all affected members in our study developed AVB 
before the age of 40, highlighting a significantly earlier onset in this 
family.  Conduction system disorders typically precede the onset 
of DCM by several years to a decade or more in LMNA-related 
conditions [13]. Given the poor prognosis associated with LMNA 
mutation carriers—especially those who develop early conduction 
defects—early genetic screening and identification are critical for 
improving clinical outcomes through timely intervention, close 
monitoring, and preventive management [14]. 
To date, 498 distinct LMNA mutations and 300 protein 
variants have been documented; these mutations and variants are 
collectively associated with a diverse range of diseases that are 
collectively termed "laminopathy" (http://www.umd.be/LMNA/). 
LMNA gene mutations are implicated in Emery–Dreifuss muscular 
dystrophy [15], limb-girdle muscular dystrophy type 1B [16], DCM 
with conduction defect [10], autosomal recessive Charcot-Marie-
Tooth disease [17], familial partial lipodystrophy type Dunnigan 
[18], myoadenylat deaminase [19], Hutchinson–Gilford progeria 
syndrome [20], restrictive dermopathy [21], and other conditions. 
In the present study, we identified a heterozygous mutation, c.1609-
1G>C (exon 10, NM_170707), in a multigenerational family affected 
by AVB. In computational prediction suggested that this splice-site 
variant would lead to exon 10 skipping, which was subsequently 
validated through cDNA sequencing and electrophoresis. Given its 
location at a canonical splice acceptor site, this mutation may result 
in isoform switching—the generation of alternative splicing variants 
with altered function. We propose that the aberrant isoform in this 
family exhibits tissue-specific expression, preferentially impairing 
cardiac conduction tissue while sparing myocardium or other muscle 
systems. This may underlie the cardiac-predominant phenotype 
observed in our pedigree. In a similar investigation, a c.1609-3C>G 
variant in LMNA was identified within a family with limb-girdle 
muscular dystrophy; notably, at least three affected relatives exhibited 
cardiac involvement distinct from the primary muscular symptoms 
[22]. Although further studies are imperative to fully elucidate the 
clinical significance of LMNA splicing mutations, our results confirm 
that these mutations manifest some degree of pathogenicity and can 
elicit diverse clinical phenotypes.
The advent of gene sequencing has unraveled an expanding 
spectrum of pathogenic genes associated with inherited AVB. Genetic 
mutations lie at the crux of inherited AVB, precipitating anomalies 
in the cardiac conduction system. Although pacemaker implantation 
remains the mainstay of treatment, it cannot prevent conduction 
block recurrence or halt the progression of cardiac disease. Animal 
experiments have demonstrated the benefits of gene therapies such as 
gene replacement therapy, gene editing therapy, and gene intervention 
therapy in the treatment of inherited arrhythmias [23]. Gene editing 
platforms like CRISPR-Cas9 facilitate precise modifications of 
mutated genes, making gene editing therapy for inherited AVB 
feasible and practical. In our study, the LMNA mutation identified 
is a canonical splice-site variant, which differs mechanistically from 
more commonly encountered missense mutations that result in 
altered protein products. This distinction may offer a therapeutic

metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS4 (6.0)
metadata.author: Liangliang Zhang1#
metadata.title: A Novel Mutation in the LMNA Gene-Associated Hereditary Atrioventricular Block

page_content:
5
Liangliang Zhang, et al., Annals of Clinical Case Reports - Cardiovascular Medicine   
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2745
advantage, as splice-correcting strategies, such as CRISPR-mediated 
splice correction or antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) therapies, are 
particularly well-suited to restore normal transcript processing 
without the need for full gene replacement. These RNA-targeted 
approaches are being actively explored in other splice-related diseases 
and could potentially be adapted for LMNA-related AVB. Therefore, 
understanding the specific nature of the mutation not only aids in 
diagnosis and family screening but also informs individualized 
therapeutic planning, laying the groundwork for future clinical 
intervention strategies tailored to this family’s genetic profile.
One notable limitation of this study is that genetic sequencing 
was only performed on second-generation (II) family members. 
Due to the death of the first-generation (I) proband, genotypic 
validation could not be conducted, leaving the precise origin of 
the LMNA mutation unconfirmed within the pedigree. Moreover, 
third-generation (III) members were not screened, precluding the 
assessment of whether the variant is present in asymptomatic or 
pre-symptomatic individuals. This limitation hinders the evaluation 
of the variant’s penetrance and potential age-dependent expression, 
both of which are critical for interpreting pathogenicity. As a result, 
the causal relationship between the LMNA variant and AVB in this 
family remains suggestive rather than conclusive, and further studies 
involving extended family members and larger cohorts are warranted. 
Moreover, this study relied exclusively on cDNA sequencing and 
electrophoresis for verifying the variable splicing mutations of the 
LMNA gene; further cellular and animal experiments are needed 
to elucidate the complete clinical significance of LMNA splicing 
mutations.
Conclusion
This study revealed a novel mutation site (NM_170707.4: c.1609-
1G>C) within the LMNA gene that is closely associated with AVB 
occurrence among a single-family lineage. The findings underscore 
the importance of genetic factors in AVB pathogenesis.

and Technology Program (ZDSYS20220606100801004, 
SGDX20230116092459009, JCYJ20220530144211025,

metadata.title: When the Heart Talks to the Brain: Rethinking Cardiovascular-Neurodegenerative Interfaces

page_content:
1
Annals of Clinical Case Reports
Remedy Publications LLC., | http://anncaserep.com/ 2025 | Volume 10 | Article 2765
When the Heart Talks to the Brain: Rethinking 
Cardiovascular-Neurodegenerative Interfaces
Case Report
Published: 16 Aug, 2025
Abstract
Emerging research reveals a bidirectional interface between cardiovascular diseases—such as atrial 
fibrillation (AF) and heart failure (HF)—and neurodegenerative disorders, including Alzheimer’s 
disease (AD) and Parkinson’s disease (PD). While traditional models have emphasized shared risk 
factors such as aging, chronic inflammation, and metabolic dysfunction, newer evidence points 
to a more dynamic and causative framework: a reciprocal interactome composed of signaling 
molecules, extracellular vehicles, and neurohormonal circuits linking cardiac and cerebral systems. 
Cardiokines (e.g., natriuretic peptides, FGF21), neurokines (e.g., BDNF, NGF), exosomes carrying 
noncoding RNAs, and systemic axes such as the renin–angiotensin–aldosterone system (RAAS) 
and hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis act as molecular bridges that mediate cross-organ 
communication. This review shifts focus from risk association to causative molecular dialogue, 
demonstrating how these interactomes drive remodeling, dysfunction, and progressive degeneration 
in both systems and repositions the heart–brain axis as a site of active disease–disease interaction, 
where reciprocal complications emerge from disrupted signaling rather than isolated end-organ 
pathology. Three clinical vignettes are presented to illustrate the translational relevance of this 
model. We propose that therapeutic strategies targeting these inter-organs signaling networks—
rather than treating individual organ dysfunction in isolation—may offer a more effective and 
systems-level approach to managing age-related syndromes.
Keywords: Cardiovascular diseases; Neurodegenerative disorders; Atrial fibrillation; Heart 
failure; Alzheimer’s disease; Parkinson’s disease; Interactomes; Cardiokines; Neurokines; 
Exosomes
Jin Ju1,2* and Zhiguo Wang1,2*
1Department of Pharmacy, the First Affiliated Hospital of Jinan University, Guangzhou 510630, China
2Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory for Chronic Disease Interactive Network Research, Jinan University, 
Guangzhou 510632, China
OPEN ACCESS
 *Correspondence:
Zhiguo Wang, Department of 
Pharmacy, the First Affiliated Hospital 
of Jinan University, Jinan University 
Panyu Campus, 85 Xingye Boulevard, 
Panyu District, Guangzhou, Guangdong 
511436, China, Tel: +86 18933954959;
E-mail: wzgmails@foxmail.com
Jin Ju, Guangdong Provincial Key 
Laboratory for Chronic Disease 
Interactive Network Research, Jinan 
University, Guangzhou 510632, China,
E-mail: jjisoutman@live.com
Received Date: 29 Jul 2025
Accepted Date: 13 Aug 2025
Published Date: 16 Aug 2025
Citation: 
Ju J, Wang Z. When the Heart Talks to 
the Brain: Rethinking Cardiovascular-
Neurodegenerative Interfaces. Ann Clin 
Case Rep. 2025; 10: 2765.
ISSN: 2474-1655.

Wang. This is an open access 
article distributed under the Creative 
Commons Attribution License, which 
permits unrestricted use, distribution, 
and reproduction in any medium, 
provided the original work is properly 
cited.
Introduction: Beyond Shared Risk Factors
Cardiovascular diseases like atrial fibrillation (AF) and heart failure (HF), and neurodegenerative 
diseases such as Alzheimer’s (AD) and Parkinson’s (PD), are traditionally treated as isolated 
aging-related conditions. While traditionally managed in silos by distinct medical specialties, 
emerging research uncovering high rates of co-occurrence and overlapping pathophysiology 
challenges this dichotomy and highlights their interdependence [1-8]. Conditions such as AF and 
HF are now recognized not only as contributors to vascular dementia and cognitive decline but 
also as active players in the progression of neurodegenerative diseases like AD and PD. Likewise, 
neurodegeneration may influence cardiac health through autonomic dysregulation, altered circadian 
rhythms, and systemic inflammation. These new observations suggest the presence of a new type of 
disease-disease interactions (DDIs): reciprocal complications [8].
The recognition of overlapping molecular drivers—such as mitochondrial dysfunction, chronic 
inflammation, oxidative stress, and impaired proteostasis—suggests that these disorders should not 
be viewed in isolation. Rather, they represent interconnected nodes within a broader aging-related 
network. Increasing evidence suggests that molecular signals originating in one organ actively 
influence pathology in the other. The concept of interactomes—complex networks of tissue-to-tissue 
molecular communication—offers a more accurate model for understanding these bidirectional 
interfaces or reciprocal complications [8]. Instead of attributing comorbidity to coincidence, 
interactomes point to causative reciprocity. Understanding and intervening in these cross-talk 
mechanisms may redefine prevention and treatment of both cardiovascular and neurodegenerative 
diseases. This systems-level perspective opens new avenues for early diagnosis, shared biomarkers, 
and therapeutics that transcend traditional boundaries.
